title: An Eco-Metabolistic Framework for Sustainable Architecture
descriptions:
The grant proposal, titled "An Eco-Metabolistic Framework for Sustainable Architecture," seeks to address the global crisis of material depletion through an interdisciplinary approach focused on sustainable building practices and the utilization of bio-based materials. The project aims to overcome challenges in transitioning to bio-based materials in architecture by developing a novel eco-metabolistic framework. This framework will enable the design of carbon-neutral, renewable, and materially optimized solutions through research-by-design methods. The project will investigate materials such as glulam, bio-polymer composites, and bioluminescent bacteria, utilizing computational modeling networks for predictive modeling, adaptive fabrication, and environmental sensing.

By conceptualizing architecture as a continual construction beyond building completion, the project aims to generate outcomes that promote participatory practices, sustainable design, socially conscious models of production, and democratic production processes. The proposed project challenges traditional design agency and offers new practices to leverage the short lifespans of bio-based materials for sustainable architecture.

Materials such as glulam, bio-polymer composites, and bioluminescent bacteria will be investigated, with a focus on predictive modelling, adaptive fabrication, and environmental sensing.
